;周四上午，香港在持续不到三个小时的黄色暴雨警告期间记录了超过 10,000 次云对地闪电。

;

;早上 5 点 15 分发出并在早上 8 点取消的黄色信号，意味着大雨已经下过或预计将在整个城市上空下过，每小时降雨量超过 30 毫米。一些地区被警告有发生严重水浸的风险。

;

;“离岛区坪洲和屯门区的雨量特别大，每小时或预计会有超过 70 毫米的雨量[已经下降] ”，天气预报员在早上 6 点 23 分说。

;

;天文台气温飙升至 34.6 度，香港记录了一年中最热的一天

;

;超过 3,000 次云对地雷击

;

;天文台表示，“时速达 100 公里或以上的猛烈阵风可能会继续影响香港”，并补充说，市民应寻求安全避难所并离开水域

;

;劳工处提醒雇主及承建商作出必要的工作安排，并采取适当措施保障进行电力工作的员工的安全。

;

;香港天文台发出暴雨黄色警告, 1 小时后取消

;

;气象学家早些时候表示，尽管台风玛娃绕过香港，但对香港产生了深远的影响，为 5 月带来了创纪录的气温，并造成了严重的空气污染。

;菲律宾三个孩子的母亲 Stella Sibonga 迫切希望结束一段她不想要的婚姻.但在这个天主教徒占多数的国家，离婚是非法的，而且法院宣布无效离婚需要数年时间。

;

;菲律宾是梵蒂冈以外唯一禁止离婚的地方，天主教会对社会有很大影响– 反对这种做法，反对它的教义。

;

;支持离婚合法化的人说，这项禁令使配偶难以摆脱暴力或其他虐待行为，甚至难以友好地断绝关系。

;< p>;想要结束婚姻的人可以要求法院宣布婚姻无效或宣布婚姻从一开始就无效，但政府可以对这些决定提出上诉。

;

;法律程序缓慢且昂贵– 在一个饱受贫困困扰的国家，案件的费用可能高达 10,000 美元或更多 – 无法保证成功，一些寻求更快结果的人会落入在线骗局。

;

;“我不明白为什么Sibonga 说，她花了 11 年的时间试图摆脱父母在她怀孕后强迫她结婚的婚姻。

;

;Sibonga 的官司始于 2012 年，当时她以丈夫所谓的“心理无行为能力”为由向法院申请取消婚姻，这是终止婚姻关系的理由之一。

;

;“终止强奸儿童行为从今天开始”：菲律宾提高了同意强奸儿童的年龄16

;

;经过五年和 3,500 美元的法律费用，法官终于同意了。然而，这位前家政工人的解脱是短暂的。

;

;作为政府法定代表，负责保护婚姻制度的副检察长办公室在 2019 年成功地对该决定提出上诉。< /p>;

;Sibonga 表示，她请求上诉法院推翻其裁决，但仍在等待答复。

;

;“为什么我们，那些经历过痛苦、遗弃和虐待的人，被受到法律的制裁？”住在马尼拉附近的 45 岁的 Sibonga 说。 “我们想要的只是自由。”

;

;在菲律宾，反对离婚最有力的反对者是天主教会，它也反对堕胎和避孕药具。

;

;大约 78%根据官方人口普查数据，该国 1.1 亿人口中有 10% 是天主教徒，许多政客都对在敏感的社会问题上与教会发生矛盾持谨慎态度。

;

;但国会近年来取得了重大胜利。

;

;尽管遭到教会的强烈反对，2012 年通过了一项有争议的节育法。

;

;2018 年，众议院的多数党和反对党批准了一项离婚法案，但后来在参议院陷入僵局.这是第一次这样的提议走到这一步。

;

;民意调查公司 Social Weather Stations 进行的调查显示，菲律宾人对离婚的态度发生了转变。

;

;2005 年，43% 的人离婚的菲律宾人支持“为不可调和的分居夫妇”离婚合法化，而 45% 的人不同意。

;

;2017 年的同一项调查显示，53% 的人赞成，而只有 32% 的人不同意。

;

;一群立法者现在正在领导一场新的离婚合法化运动，向众议院和参议院提交了几项法案。

;

;“我们不会破坏任何婚姻，”国会议员兼作家埃德塞尔·拉格曼 (Edcel Lagman) 说其中一项法案。

;

;拉格曼表示，离婚是为了“无法修复的功能失调的婚姻”，将离婚合法化将使妇女及其子女摆脱“不宽容和虐待的丈夫”。

;

;之前在他当选后，总统小费迪南德·马科斯 (Ferdinand Marcos Jnr) 表示，该国应该考虑允许离婚，但坚称这并不容易。

;

;获得法院命令结束婚姻的繁琐程序催生了提供安全保障的在线诈骗

;

;法新社事实核查人员发现，许多 Facebook 帖子散布有关撤销法律程序的虚假信息，以吸引客户，这突显了欺诈者利用虚假信息获利的全球趋势。

;

;一名受害者说，她被收取了相当于 2,400 美元的取消服务费用，但结果证明是假的。

;

;她现在正在考虑皈依伊斯兰教，希望能离婚根据穆斯林法律。

;

;“我真的在尝试所有可能的选择，只是为了再次单身，”她在不愿透露姓名的情况下告诉法新社。 “废除婚姻需要很长时间，成本很高，而且没有保证，所以我正在寻找一种更方便的方法。”

;

;家庭法专家 Katrina Legarda 说，因虚假服务而堕落的人数表明，有一个“迫切需要”新立法。

;

;但菲律宾天主教主教团的杰罗姆·塞西拉诺神父表示，菲律宾应该“自豪”成为梵蒂冈以外唯一“坚持传统的婚姻观念”。

;

;“一段关系中总会有不完美的地方，”他说。

;

;Secillano 说与施暴的伴侣离婚会“延续暴力”，因为施暴者会继续虐待她们的下一个伴侣。

;

;“你实际上并没有治愈疾病本身，”他说。

;

;没有孩子或丈夫，谢谢：菲律宾妇女反抗社会< /h3>;

;Sibonga 从小就是天主教徒，但为了避免通奸的指控而停止去教堂。

;

;她有一个长期的男朋友，但在她的第一次婚姻合法之前不能和他结婚

;

;她的案子拖了这么久在菲律宾并不罕见，菲律宾脆弱的司法系统可能需要数年时间才能解决即使是小问题。

;

;“人们认为因为我在技术上仍处于婚姻状态，我是一个罪人，”她说。 “他们真的相信上帝所联合的东西是不可分割的。真的吗？即使你的丈夫想杀了你，即使在他做了一切之后，离婚仍然是不允许的？”

;

;Sibonga 说她与丈夫的关系受到了创伤，并促使她两次尝试自杀。< /p>;

;在允许离婚之前，她不希望她的孩子结婚。

;

;“我告诉他们他们可以同居，想生多少孩子就生多少，但我永远不会同意他们要结婚了，”她说。 “我只是不想让他们像我一样结束。”

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 08:50:02 +0800 Philippine senators blame regulators for ‘not doing their job’ in controlling Pogo scamshttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3222474/philippine-senators-blame-regulators-not-doing-their-job-controlling-pogo-scams?utm_source=rss_feed

;参议员批评政府监管机构允许人口贩运团伙利用菲律宾离岸赌博运营商 (Pogos) ) 作为运行在线诈骗和推广虚假加密货币投资的“合法掩护”。

;

;该行业于 2016 年在菲律宾兴起并呈指数级增长，因为运营商利用该国宽松的博彩法瞄准中国客户，

;

;在参议院关于从马尼拉西北部的 Pogo 综合设施中解救 1,000 多名外国工人的听证会上，立法者 Risa Hontiveros 警告说，对商业模式视而不见将导致有组织的犯罪团伙“以我们政府永远无法应对的惊人速度增长”。

;

;参议员 Sherwin Gatchalian 直言不讳地批评在线游戏公司，指责行业监管机构 Pagcor 腐败且未能监督

;

;“网络博彩公司被用作诈骗[和]人口贩卖的幌子，因为菲律宾娱乐娱乐公司腐败。这是底线，”Gatchalian 周二告诉参议院，他呼吁彻底禁止受犯罪影响的行业，因为它给菲律宾带来了“国际耻辱”。

;

;“你没有做好你的工作.你闭上了眼睛，你的检查员变得腐败了，”他补充道。

;

;菲律宾娱乐公司助理副总裁 Jessa Mariz Fernandez 承认她的部门忽视了与政府机构合作的必要性，并派遣官员观察 Pogo 枢纽，菲律宾每日问询者报报道。

;

;在与中国客户存在“政治风险”的情况下，菲律宾是否会禁止网络博彩公司？

;

;网络博彩公司在鼎盛时期雇佣了超过 30 万名中国工人，但大流行病的发生率更高税收和执法行动迫使许多人在其他地方开展业务。

;

;北京一再警告中国公民不要在菲律宾的 Pogos 工作，这导致了包括绑架和谋杀在内的一系列犯罪活动。

;

;根据警方数据，Gatchalian 表示，在 2019 年 11 月至 2023 年 3 月期间，报告了大约 113 起与 POGO 相关的犯罪，包括绑架和人口贩运。

;

;政府在 2022 年表示将停止运营作为打击该行业的一部分，175 家离岸博彩公司和驱逐约 40,000 名中国工人，该行业每年为经济带来 1900 亿比索（32 亿美元）的收入。

;

;Hontiveros，他最近参观了一个离岸博彩公司大院当局解救了至少 1,090 名人口贩运受害者，其中包括中国人、菲律宾人和印度尼西亚人，他们表示，如果他们反抗，他们将被迫从事诈骗工作，并被关押在“暗室”。

;

;“每天，他们都会努力吸引外国人，通常是男人，爱上他们，然后强迫他们投资加密货币，”她说。

;

;这位参议员声称一群中国公民在里面经营着一个“诈骗中心”在 5 月 4 日的突击搜查中发现了一个转租的办公室。

;

;大约 12 名为该集团工作的人，包括七名中国人和四名印度尼西亚人，因警方的行动而被捕。

;

;两家被控将财产出租给该团伙的公司否认参与了人口贩卖骗局，其中一家公司声称它“只是将办公室转租给了中国客户”，而中国客户最初将自己宣传为游戏服务提供商。;

;香港期待已久的加密货币规则启动了新的虚拟资产监管制度周四生效，专家称这给该市的交易所带来了更大的负担，但到目前为止并未阻碍业务发展。

;

;该市的零售交易规则和许可指南于上周完成，代表了该市的零售交易规则和许可指南之一继去年一系列崩溃之后，随着香港向动荡的数字资产行业敞开怀抱，世界上最严格的集中式加密货币交易所的监管框架。

;

;自本月起，加密货币交易所必须申请牌照与证券及期货事务监察委员会 (SFC) 一起向香港消费者销售和营销。随着证监会开始处理牌照申请，已经在香港拥有大量业务的交易所有一年的时间继续运营，同时他们准备遵守新规则或退出市场。

;

;“重大的合规义务并没有阻止希望在香港立足的加密货币公司的兴趣，”香港律师事务所 Baker McKenzie 的合伙人 Joy Lam 说。 “我们收到了大量希望在香港获得许可的现有和新市场进入者的请求。”

;

;决定留下来的中心化交易所将必须遵守广泛的要求，涵盖以下领域：用户入职、资产托管、网络安全和公司治理。根据证监会的说法，他们还需要对他们承认的加密货币代币进行尽职调查，并且只提供那些具有大市值和高流动性的代币。

;

;“这将需要大量的准备工作和投资成本来建立一个能够满足要求的交易平台，”Latham & Watkins 的律师在周二发表的一篇博文中写道。

;

;香港金融服务及库务局局长 Christopher Hui 在 3 月份的一次活动中表示，超过 80 家来自中国内地和海外的公司表示有兴趣在香港设立 Web3 业务。

;

;OKX 和火币等公开表示正在申请在香港经营的牌照。两者都是世界上最大的加密货币交易所之一，并且都在中国大陆成立。两家公司表示，他们已开始在香港接纳零售用户，同时努力遵守新规则。

;

;香港证监会将于 6 月 1 日最终确定香港零售加密货币交易规则

;

; BitMEX 曾经是业内知名的顶级交易所，以提供允许交易者将其资本杠杆化高达 100 倍的衍生产品而闻名，上周表示它将为香港用户推出一款单独的应用程序，该应用程序仅提供现货交易。

;

;首席执行官 Stephan Lutz 说，在 BitMEX 的主要全球服务之外为香港发布新的应用程序是“确保它完全符合香港监管机构的期望的最安全、最合规的方式”。

;

;Gate.io 是一家拥有 10 年历史的加密货币交易所，周二还为该市推出了一个名为 Gate.HK 的专用平台。该公司首席执行官 Kevin Lee 表示，鉴于“该地区作为全球金融中心的战略意义”以及最近引入的证监会发牌制度，该公司正在“积极寻求”在香港获得许可。

;

;香港的散户投资者已经可以开始使用已在该市推出服务的加密货币交易所。根据新规定，零售交易者只能购买具有大市值的代币，例如比特币和以太币。

;

;但是，由于宽限期，并非所有交易所都会立即获得完全许可。

;

;“这意味着在这一年的过渡期内，我们将同时拥有以不同标准运营的持牌交易所和非持牌交易所，因此投资者在选择加密交易所之前需要谨慎并做好功课Baker McKenzie 的 Lam 说。

;

;SFC 发牌事务主管 Elizabeth Wong 在上周的新闻发布会。

;

;与此同时，当地加密行业希望监管机构尽快扩大合法虚拟资产活动的范围，以包括衍生品和稳定币等东西，这些是由另一种资产支持的加密货币，通常

;

;“对冲基金等机构参与者对监管良好的加密货币衍生品市场有着巨大的需求，但目前的[虚拟资产交易平台]制度不允许香港普华永道香港加密货币和 Web3 联席主管 Peter Brewin 表示，交易所提供这些产品，可能会迫使这种活动离岸。

;

;“为加密货币衍生品提供受监管的交易场所的能力可能会吸引大量业务进入香港，交易量有可能大大高于现货交易，”Brewin 补充道。

;

;加密货币交易所 OKX 将在香港申请虚拟资产牌照

;

;香港普华永道法律网络公司 Tiang & Partners 投资基金主管 Gaven Cheong 表示，未来一年兴趣的增加可能会导致香港散户投资者可以获得的代币类型和数量增加。它还可能推动稳定币发行的激增，以及与持牌交易所合作提供法定货币兑换等服务的传统银行和金融机构的增加。

;

;虽然许多业内人士承认新法规是一个很大的作为在加密货币领域提供清晰度的第一步，该行业也在展望下一步。

;

;“[香港]监管机构在展示具有护栏的虚拟资产方面做得非常出色地方，”麦格理资本香港和中国互联网和数字资产研究主管 Esme Pau 说。 “展望未来，维护护栏和简化整个虚拟资产生态系统价值链将至关重要。”

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Draft of Queen hit song shows Freddie Mercury originally called it Mongolian Rhapsodyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3222519/draft-queen-hit-song-shows-freddie-mercury-originally-called-it-mongolian-rhapsody?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;早在皇后乐队的“波西米亚狂想曲”成为世界上播放量最大的歌曲之一之前, 乐队的主唱 Freddie Mercury 考虑了为这部时长六分钟的摇滚歌剧取一个不同的名字。

;

;Mercury 早期创意想法的涂鸦表明，主唱最初考虑将乐队最受欢迎的唱片命名为“蒙古语”狂想曲”，纽约时报报道。

;

;可以看到标题是在一家已倒闭的英国航空公司 British Midland 的便条纸上写下并被划掉的。在被划掉的字样上方，Mercury 写下了“Bohemian”。

;

;“Bohemian Rhapsody”于 1975 年发行，并于 2021 年获得美国唱片业协会正式认证的钻石。

;

; Mercury 从来没有解释过标题的意思。皇后乐队的传记作者吉姆·詹金斯 (Jim Jenkins) 告诉《泰晤士报》，默丘里“从不喜欢解释”他的歌词或歌曲名称。

;

;据《电讯报》报道，默丘里在谈到《波西米亚狂想曲》时说：“这是其中之一具有这种幻想感觉的歌曲。我认为人们应该只听它，想它，然后自己决定它对他们说什么。”

;

;文具是属于女王的大约 1,5000 件物品之一据英国广播公司报道，默丘里的好友玛丽奥斯汀将在伦敦苏富比拍卖行拍卖这位歌手，后者继承了他的大部分财产。拍卖会将于 9 月上线。

;

;“这些收藏让你更深入地了解这个人和我认识的人，”奥斯汀告诉英国媒体。 72 岁的奥斯汀在接受 BBC 采访时说，她正在出售这些物品，“因为我需要整理我的事务”。

;

;弗雷迪·默丘里拥有的几乎所有东西都将被拍卖

;

;据苏富比拍卖行称，该藏品包括 15 页“波西米亚狂想曲”的早期草稿。拍卖行在一份新闻稿中表示，这首歌的歌词可以在音符中看到。草稿还显示了这首歌的一段变体。

;

;据《泰晤士报》报道，而不是“妈妈/刚杀了一个人/用枪顶着他的头/扣动了我的扳机，现在他死了，” Mercury 考虑：“妈妈/战争开始了/我今晚必须离开/我必须站起来战斗。”

;

;这些汇票估计价值高达 150 万美元，据《泰晤士报》报道。

;

;女王的其他流行歌曲的草稿，包括“我们是冠军”，以及水星的舞台服装和个人物品也将被拍卖，预计收益将捐赠给慈善机构。 BBC。

;

;苏富比发言人没有立即回应置评请求。

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 06:50:01 +0800 Shangri-La Dialogue: why the US and Chinese defence ministers should meet – and what stands in their wayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3222445/shangri-la-dialogue-why-us-and-chinese-defence-ministers-should-meet-and-what-stands-their-way?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.01 06:00;
;;

;One of the most important security conferences on the international calendar gets under way for the 20th time in Singapore on June 2, bringing together defence ministers, military personnel and policy watchers. In the first of a three-part series, Minnie Chan examines the prospects of engagement between the defence ministers of the world's two most powerful militaries: China and the United States.

;

;When the Shangri-La Dialogue gets under way in Singapore on Friday it will bring a much needed opportunity for the military top brass of both China and the US to shake hands and add some personal warmth to their frosty relations.

;

;But that opportunity – or even just a chance encounter in the corridors of the plush Shangri-La Hotel – could be lost as the two sides still fail to see eye to eye on almost every issue in their strained relationship.

;

;As they face off in the Pacific and the South China Sea, the US defends its actions as “freedom of navigation operations”, while China insists that it will not budge on its territorial integrity and sovereignty.

;

;The two countries are also exchanging heated military signals around Taiwan, with the US ramping up its military support despite Beijing's repeated warnings, and the People's Liberation Army inching ever closer to the island in its drills.

;

;Any meeting in Singapore is likely to be tense but observers say the stakes of the superpowers not talking to each other in the new cold war era are grave.

;

;Tensions between Beijing and Washington were expected to improve this year, with the US and Chinese presidents meeting in Bali last November and agreeing to better communication.

;

;But then came the downing of a suspected Chinese spy balloon in American waters, prompting US Secretary of State Antony Blinken to cancel a trip to China.

;

;Washington's arms sales to Taiwan and US suspicions that Beijing is arming Russia in the Ukraine war have added to the mistrust.

;

;Ni Lexiong, a professor with the Shanghai University of Political Science and Law, said the Pentagon was also ramping up military pressure on China, with plans to deploy an Ohio-class submarine to the Korean peninsula for regular patrols and Nato looking to set up its first office in Japan.

;

;“The US has tried its utmost to rope all China's neighbours in its camp to further isolate and contain China, putting the Chinese military delegation in a very disadvantageous position when they are encountering foreign counterparts, especially the Americans, at the [Shangri-La Dialogue],” he said.

;

;The result was an international environment that had become more unfavourable towards China, Ni said.

;

;Nevertheless, Defence Minister General Li Shangfu will head the Chinese delegation to the conference, and is expected to meet foreign counterparts.

;

;US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin will also attend and give a speech on Saturday. Li is expected to make an address about “China's new security initiatives” on Sunday. In both cases, attendees will have a chance to ask questions of the speakers.

;

;The chances of a Li-Austin meeting, however, seem low, with the Pentagon saying on Tuesday that Beijing had rejected such a proposal after reportedly sitting on the request for weeks.

;

;“The United States and the Department of Defence have an outstretched hand on this question of military-to-military engagement and we have yet to have had a consistently willing partner [in China],” US assistant secretary of defence for Indo-Pacific security affairs Ely Ratner said last week.

;

;Senior Colonel Tan Kefei, a spokesman for China's military, on Wednesday said the US was “solely responsible” for the “difficulty of communication”, and that “dialogue cannot be done without principles”.

;

;A major stumbling block to a meeting are the sanctions the US has placed on the Chinese general, according to Zhou Chenming, a researcher with the Beijing-based Yuan Wang military science and technology think tank.

;

;The sanctions relate to China's purchase of SU-35 combat aircraft in 2017 and S-400 surface-to-air missile system-related equipment from Russia in 2018.

;

;“But Li's attendance is still a goodwill response to US President Joe Biden's earlier remark that he expects a thaw in frosty relations with China soon,” Zhou said.

;

;“The PLA is still willing to keep the military-to-military relationship with its American counterpart as a stabiliser in China-US ties.”

;

;As the US and China woo with military drills, who will Southeast Asia choose?

;

;Zhou said the PLA was unhappy that the US, in asking for the meeting, refused to lift the sanctions it had imposed on Li.

;

;“If the Pentagon said that the sanctions do not affect communication between the two militaries, why couldn't Washington simply just lift them?”

;

;Zhou said Beijing also felt betrayed by Biden, who had promised Xi in their personal calls to “improve bilateral ties”, but had not kept his word.

;

;Zhou said an example was that Biden said the White House was discussing a decision to lift the sanctions on Li, but it was “turned down overnight by the State Department”.

;

;“The inconsistency of the sanction decision indicated the Biden administration was hijacked by next year's US presidential election – it's 'politically incorrect' to show weakness to China, making Beijing feel a meeting between Li and Austin is less meaningful if Washington keeps its 'unfriendly attitude' towards China,” Zhou said.

;

;The Shangri-La Dialogue was initiated in 2002 but Beijing has not always sent defence ministers as its representatives.

;

;In the past, Beijing sought to play down the importance of the dialogue – seen as a platform dominated by Washington and its Western allies – and sent lower-level PLA officials.

;

;That approach changed when the forum marked its 10th anniversary in 2011. China sent a high-level delegation led by then-defence minister general Liang Guanglie.

;

;China then returned to sending lower-level officers until 2019 when Wei Fenghe, Li's predecessor as defence minister, represented the PLA at the dialogue and had his first in-person meeting with his US counterpart Patrick Shanahan. Wei returned to the dialogue last year and met Austin.

;

;Zhou Bo, a senior fellow at the Centre for International Security and Strategy at Tsinghua University and a China Forum expert, said the Shangri-La Dialogue had since become not only the most important defence summit in Asia but also the world's second most influential security forum after the Munich Security Conference, held in Germany since 1963.

;

;“Chinese senior military officials understand the importance of letting their voice be heard by the international community, with the Shangri-La Dialogue being an effective and valuable platform,” he said.

;

;Taiwan may pay 'unthinkable' price for free US weapons, says ex-minister

;

;He said the Chinese delegation this year would focus on explaining China's position on the war in Ukraine.

;

;“The Ukraine war has become a watershed event for many countries' foreign policy, and China's long-standing close relationship is under a lot of scrutiny, especially in the shadow of potential conflicts in the Taiwan Strait,” Zhou Bo said.

;

;“The Shangri-La Dialogue will provide a timely opportunity for the PLA to communicate with its foreign counterparts directly.”

;

;Zhou Bo, a retired senior colonel, said the PLA delegates were also likely to use the opportunity to explain Beijing's military responses over Taiwan following the stopover visit by Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen to the US in April and the visit by former US House speaker Nancy Pelosi to the self-ruled island last summer.

;

;“[The] PLA's activities in response are actually measured and appropriate … and that should be understood by our Asian neighbours,” he said.

;

;Taiwan has become a main concern for countries in the region. It was first mentioned by former US secretary of defence James Mattis at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2017, provoking the PLA delegation to denounce the US military's “attempt to support Taiwan independence”.

;

;In his address at the forum in 2019 and again last year, Wei specifically gave stern warnings to “external forces” and Taiwan independence-leaning forces, saying the PLA “will fight at all costs” against “Taiwan independence”.

;

;Zhou Chenming and Zhou Bo said the PLA delegation this year would tell neighbours that “peaceful reunification” remained Beijing's top priority on the Taiwan issue, an approach endorsed by Xi's work report to the Communist Party's 20th national congress in October.

;

;Taiwan intervention and US conflict among top worries for Chinese: poll

;

;Drew Thompson, a visiting senior research fellow at the National University of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy, said there would be opportunities for encounters between senior officers of the two militaries and any brief meeting might help reduce the risk of conflict.

;

;“Conveying authoritative messages at the highest possible level is important to reduce misunderstanding and the risk of miscalculation,” he said.

;

;Bonnie Glaser, head of the German Marshall Fund's Indo-Pacific programme, said the decline in contact between the US and Chinese militaries was in neither party's interest.

;

;“Our two militaries used to have regular dialogues, exchanges and port calls. I believe that the absence of dialogue increases the risk of misunderstanding and accidents between our militaries doesn't serve our two countries' interests,” she said.

;

;Zhou Chenming of the Yuan Wang think tank agreed that any meeting would help defuse tensions.

;

;“Pushing the envelope in a civilised way on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is much better than the two militaries meeting each other on the battlefield,” he said.

;The recent Cathay Pacific discrimination scandal has cast doubt on the local government's “Hello Hong Kong” campaign. After a social media post in which a Mandarin-speaking passenger accused cabin crew of mocking passengers' English-language abilities on a flight from Chengdu to Hong Kong went viral on the mainland, Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu, the People's Daily and Xinhua News Agency condemned the discrimination and demanded the airline deal seriously with the issue.

;

;Though Cathay Pacific quickly fired the attendants and its CEO apologised in Mandarin, the incident has cast a shadow on Hong Kong's global public relations campaign and the company's reputation.

;

;In 2019, Cathay Pacific faced a backlash from the mainland over some employees' support of the anti-government protests. Then, during the Covid-19 pandemic, the airline had to suspend most of its flights and has only recently begun rebuilding its route network.

;

;As part of the government's campaign to boost tourism, Cathay Pacific has rolled out large ticket giveaways, including one targeted at the Greater Bay Area. Travellers who were meant to happily fly to Hong Kong and spend their time and money here now might start to wonder if they will face the same discrimination.

;

;This is far from the first time that tourism has been a source of tension between Hongkongers and visitors from the mainland. Not long after the border between the Hong Kong and the mainland reopened, residents of To Kwa Wan and other areas started complaining about the crowds of tourists, visitors from the mainland eating takeaway meals in the street and the disruption caused by tour buses.

;

;The authorities have acted to try to address the issue of overcrowding in certain districts, but it is likely that similar problems will continue to present themselves in the city's tourist hotspots.

;

;Discrimination of the sort on display on the Cathay Pacific flight from Chengdu must not be tolerated, particularly in a global city that wants to present itself as being open to visitors from anywhere in the world. Showing respect and providing appropriate assistance to people from different cultures is essential to the success of the city's tourism industry.

;

;However, as the authorities are well aware, negative sentiment towards people from the mainland has long existed in Hong Kong. Legal action might provide a temporary solution, but it will not tackle the root of the problem. It is important that the Hong Kong authorities and Cathay Pacific's management recognise this fact.

;

;Cathay scandal: creating an inclusive Hong Kong is everyone's business

;

;One of the biggest factors is the problem of language. Mandarin speakers have complained of facing discrimination in Hong Kong in the past. There are often reports of conflicts arising from miscommunication between mainland customers and local businesses because of language differences.

;

;The esteem in which Hongkongers' hold the English language is understandable given Hong Kong's history and its long-standing orientation towards the English-speaking world.

;

;However, according to statistics from the Tourism Board, visitors from the mainland represented 80 per cent of all arrivals to Hong Kong in March. In comparison, visitors from the US, Canada, the UK and Australia accounted for only about 3 per cent, while those from Taiwan, Macau, South Asia and Southeast Asia combined made up 12 per cent. This visitor composition poses challenges for those in the tourism industry who lack the training needed to serve mainland tourists.

;

;Hong Kong's tourism sector can no longer afford to focus on the English-speaking world, hard as that might be for some people to accept. The predominant customer groups have changed for much of the service industry, so businesses must take appropriate steps to adapt to that change.

;

;Conflict between Hongkongers and mainland tourists can also arise from an inability to manage tourists' expectations. While local tourism authorities maintain the city welcomes mainland visitors with open arms, Hong Kong's image as a shoppers' paradise has largely remained unchanged for decades.

;

;The Hong Kong government's efforts at image-building often lack appreciation for local culture. Ignoring the uniqueness of Cantonese culture in our promotional campaigns means visitors are unaware of the importance of the Cantonese language in daily life here, which increases chances for conflict.

;

;These problems will persist unless flexible measures are taken to deal with them. Negative sentiment towards mainland visitors existed before the 2019 protests and has not gone away with the end of the social unrest. Legal measures are only useful when both parties recognise what amounts to wrongdoing.

;

;Even now, there are people in Hong Kong who are likely to see the actions taken in the aftermath of the Cathay Pacific scandal as further oppression. These sentiments have their roots in the city's continuing discontent. As Xia Baolong, the director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, said last month, deeper investigation is needed to fix the issues at the heart of Hong Kong society.

;

;When incidents of discrimination occur, the Hong Kong authorities must take a more serious but pragmatic approach. They need to listen to those working in the tourism industry, understand the difficulties they face and deal with the underlying problems to prevent further tension between Hongkongers and mainland visitors.
